newsitem.title: USA: Promoter Don King sues ABC over comment.
newsitem.headline: Promoter Don King sues ABC over comment.

text.p: Boxing promoter Don King Tuesday sued ABC Inc. for defamation after its KABC-TV station broadcast a report that falsely quoted King as saying suspended heavyweight Mike Tyson doesn't belong in the sport.

While the Los Angeles station later broadcast a retraction, the lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, alleged that the report injured King's reputation as a professional boxing promoter.
Officials of ABC, a unit of Walt Disney Co., had no comment.

In the June 30 broadcast, sportscaster Rick Lozano quoted King as saying that Tyson doesn't belong in boxing. Lozano also quoted King as saying, "Shame on me if I ever again contribute to one of his paydays."
On a broadcast later that evening, Lozano retracted the statement, saying the quotes attributed to King were erroneous.

In the lawsuit, King's lawyers said the retraction failed to minimise the damage to King's professional reputation and was "merely a defensive and prophylactic device...in anticipation of litigation."
King's lawyers said the retraction should have been broadcast on a "national level."
King is seeking $1 million in compensatory damages and $5 million in punitive damages.
The World Boxing Association stripped heavyweight Mike Tyson of his ranking after Tyson bit Evander Holyfield's ears during their bout on June 28. King promoted the fight.
The Nevada State Boxing Commission has suspended Tyson and withheld his $30 million purse, pending a final ruling on the case.
